questions.text: Which substance inhibits the iron transporter on the basal side of the enterocyte?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hepcidin

Explanation:

  • This is a peptide hormone produced by the liver that regulates iron homeostasis.
  • It inhibits ferroportin, which is the iron transporter on the basal side of the enterocyte, thereby decreasing iron absorption and release into the bloodstream.

Iron homeostasis:

  • Dietary Iron conversion and absorption:
    • Most dietary iron is in the ferric (Fe³⁺) form, which needs to be converted to the ferrous (Fe²⁺) form to be absorbed.
    • Gastric secretions and reductase enzymes on the brush border of enterocytes reduce Fe³⁺ to Fe²⁺.
  • Iron absorption mechanism:
    • Iron absorption mainly occurs in the duodenum.
    • Fe²⁺ is absorbed by enterocytes via divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1)
    • Within enterocytes, some Fe²⁺ is stored in ferritin, while the rest is exported into the bloodstream by ferroportin 1 (FPN1). (Option D)
    • Hephaestin, a ferroxidase enzyme, facilitates the conversion of Fe²⁺ to Fe³⁺ as it is transported across the basolateral membrane.
  • Iron transport and storage:
    • Once in the plasma, Fe²⁺ is oxidized back to Fe³⁺ and binds to transferrin.
    • Transferrin transports iron to various tissues, where it is stored primarily in the form of ferritin and hemosiderin. (Option C)
      • Ferritin: A soluble protein complex that stores iron safely within cells, particularly in the liver, spleen, bone marrow, and intestinal mucosa. (Option B)
      • Hemosiderin: A more stable and less soluble iron-storage complex found mainly in macrophages, especially under conditions of iron overload.
  • Role of Hepcidin: (Option A)
    • Hepcidin, a peptide hormone produced by the liver, regulates iron levels by binding to ferroportin (FPN1).
    • The binding of hepcidin to ferroportin leads to the internalization and degradation of ferroportin.
    • This process reduces the export of iron from enterocytes, macrophages, and hepatocytes into the bloodstream, thereby decreasing serum iron levels.

questions.text: Identify this movement that takes place in the intestine.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Peristalisis

Explanation:

  • Peristalsis is a wave-like muscular contraction that occurs in the smooth muscle layers of the digestive tract, including the intestines. It propels food and chyme forward through the gastrointestinal tract in a unidirectional manner. This is the movement responsible for pushing the contents of the intestine through the digestive system.

Peristalsis:

  • Reflex response is initiated by the stretching of the gut wall due to the contents of the lumen.

Location:

  • It occurs throughout the gastrointestinal tract, from the esophagus to the rectum.

Mechanism:

  • Stretching triggers circular contraction behind the stimulus and relaxation in front of it.
  • The wave of contraction moves in an oral-to-caudal direction.
  • Propels the contents of the lumen forward at rates of 2 to 25 cm/s.

Regulation:

  • Peristaltic activity is influenced by autonomic input but occurs independently of extrinsic innervation.
  • Local stretch releases serotonin, activating sensory neurons that stimulate the myenteric plexus.
  • Cholinergic neurons in the myenteric plexus:
    • In retrograde direction: release substance P and acetylcholine, causing contraction behind the bolus.
    • In anterograde direction: activate the neurons releasing nitric oxide (NO) and vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP), causing relaxation ahead of the bolus

Functional Integration:

  • Peristalsis is an example of the integrated activity of the enteric nervous system.

Neurotransmitters Involved in Peristalsis

 

Neurotransmitter

Role

Mechanism

Acetylcholine (ACh)

Stimulates contraction

Acts on muscarinic receptors, increases motility

Substance P

Promotes ascending contraction

Released by mucosal stimulation, enhances orad contraction

Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide (VIP)

Promotes relaxation

Acts on smooth muscle to induce relaxation during peristalsis

Serotonin (5-HT)

Regulates motility and initiates reflex

Released from enterochromaffin cells, activates 5-HT receptors

Nitric Oxide (NO)

Mediates relaxation

Released by inhibitory neurons, assists VIP in relaxation

Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide (CGRP)

Influences sensory signaling

Modulated by serotonin, aids in coordinating reflexes

questions.text: Enteropeptidase enzyme is secreted by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Duodenum

Explanation:

  • Enteropeptidase (also known as enterokinase) is an enzyme secreted by the duodenum, specifically by the brush border cells (enterocytes) in the small intestine.
  • Its main role is to activate trypsinogen (the inactive form of trypsin) into trypsin. Trypsin then activates other pancreatic enzymes that help in protein digestion.

Enzymes of the gastrointestinal tract (GIT):

Location

Enzyme

Function

Mouth

Salivary Amylase

Breaks down starch into maltose

Lingual Lipase

Begins digestion of lipids (mainly milk fat in infants)

Stomach

Pepsinogen (activated to Pepsin)

Breaks down proteins into smaller peptides

Gastric Lipase

Breaks down lipids, especially in infants

Small Intestine

Enteropeptidase (Enterokinase)

Activates trypsinogen to trypsin

Pancreatic Amylase

Continues carbohydrate digestion (starches to maltose and dextrins)

Pancreatic Lipase

Breaks down triglycerides into monoglycerides and free fatty acids

Pancreatic Proteases (Trypsin, Chymotrypsin, Carboxypeptidase)

Break down proteins into peptides and amino acids

Pancreatic Nucleases

Breaks down nucleic acids (DNA, RNA) into nucleotides

Disaccharidases (Sucrase, Lactase, Maltase)

Break down disaccharides into monosaccharides (e.g., glucose, galactose, fructose)

Aminopeptidases

Break down peptides into amino acids

Large Intestine

Bacterial Enzymes

Ferment carbohydrates (fiber) into short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) and gases

 

Stomach (Option A): The stomach secretes gastric juice containing pepsinogen (which is activated to pepsin) for protein digestion, but it does not secrete enteropeptidase.

Jejunum (Option C): While the jejunum is part of the small intestine involved in nutrient absorption, enteropeptidase is secreted in the duodenum, not the jejunum.

Ileum (Option D): The ileum is involved in absorbing nutrients, particularly bile salts and vitamin B12, but it does not secrete enteropeptidase.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is responsible for increasing gastric motility?

choices.text: Presence of fatty food in the stomach
Presence of tryptophan in the stomach
The presence of acid in the stomach

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Distension of the stomach

Explanation:

  • Distension of the stomach (i.e., stretching of the stomach wall) is a key factor that stimulates gastric motility. This occurs because the stretch activates mechanoreceptors in the stomach wall, which then trigger the release of signals that promote motility, helping the stomach to mix and propel its contents.

Factors responsible for increasing gastric motility:

Factor

Effect on Gastric Motility

Explanation

Distension of the stomach

Increases gastric motility

Stretching of the stomach wall activates mechanoreceptors, stimulating motility.

Gastrin

Increases gastric motility

Hormone released in response to food, especially proteins, that stimulates gastric motility.

Acetylcholine (ACh)

Increases gastric motility

Released by the parasympathetic nervous system, promoting smooth muscle contraction.

Peptides and amino acids

Increases gastric motility

Presence of partially digested proteins or amino acids triggers gastrin release.

Gastric emptying reflex

Increases gastric motility

Reflex activated when food enters the duodenum, regulating the rate of gastric emptying.

Increased secretion of digestive enzymes

Increases gastric motility

The release of gastric juices and digestive enzymes aids in the mixing and movement of food.

 

Presence of fatty food in the stomach (Option A): Fatty food in the stomach actually slows gastric motility because it triggers the release of cholecystokinin (CCK), which inhibits gastric emptying.

Presence of tryptophan in the stomach (Option C): While tryptophan is an amino acid, it is not a direct factor in increasing gastric motility. Its role is more related to the synthesis of serotonin, which can affect various aspects of gastrointestinal function, but not directly promote motility in the stomach.

The presence of acid in the stomach (Option D): The presence of acid in the stomach does not directly increase gastric motility. It is more involved in digestion and the regulation of gastric secretion.

questions.text: In which of the following reflexes, gastric emptying is delayed when acidic content enters the duodenum?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option D) Enterogastric

Explanation:

Factors Inhibiting Gastric Emptying:

 

Factor

Mechanism

Acid in the duodenum

Releases secretin, inhibiting antral contraction and stimulating pyloric sphincter contraction

Products of fat digestion

Releases CCK and GIP, inhibiting gastric emptying

Hypertonic solutions in the duodenum

Releases hormones inhibiting gastric emptying

Products of protein digestion

Releases gastrin, CCK, and GIP, inhibiting gastric emptying

Large meal volume (solids)

Prolongs gastric emptying time

Stretching of duodenum

Initiates enterogastric reflex, inhibiting gastric emptying (Option D)

Sympathetic stimulation

Decreased gastric motility (by norepinephrine) and increased pyloric sphincter tone.

Hormones (CCK, GIP, secretin)

-

 

Gastrocolic (Option A): The Gastrocolic reflex is a reflex that stimulates colonic motility and promotes the movement of feces from the colon to the rectum when food enters in the stomach leading to distension.

Intestino intestinal (Option B): When a part of the intestine is over-distended, the rest of the intestine relaxes. This is called intestine intestinal reflex.

Gastroilea (Option C): The Gastroileal reflex is a reflex that stimulates the emptying of the ileum, the final portion of the small intestine, by relaxing the ileocecal valve. It is not directly related to gastric emptying or the entry of acidic content into the duodenum.

questions.text: The least frequency of slow waves is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Stomach

Explanation:

  • The Stomach has the least frequency of slow waves
  • The Interstitial Cells of Cajal (ICCs) are the pacemaker cells in the GIT, responsible for generating the slow wave rhythms that control the motility of the digestive tract.
  • These slow waves are not action potentials but can trigger action potentials if their amplitude reaches a threshold.
    • When strong enough, they result in rhythmic contractions of the smooth muscle, contributing to peristalsis and other forms of motility.
  • The frequency of slow waves in different parts of the GIT varies:

GI tract region

Frequency of Slow waves (per minute)

Stomach

3-5

Duodenum

12-20

Jejunum

8-12

Ileum

6-9

Colon

6-10

questions.text: All of the following increases gastric acid secretion except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Serotonin

Explanation:

  • Serotonin (5-HT) plays a key role in gastrointestinal motility.
  • During peristalsis, stretching of the intestinal wall triggers the release of serotonin.
  • Serotonin activates the myenteric plexus, regulating peristaltic movement.

Hormones and Enzymes Increasing Gastric Acid Secretion

  • Gastrin (Option A ruled out)
    • Source: G cells in the stomach antrum and duodenum
    • Mechanism:
      • Stimulates ECL cells to release histamine
      • Directly activates parietal cells to increase H+/K+ ATPase expression
  • Histamine (Option B ruled out)
    • Source: ECL cells (in response to gastrin)
    • Mechanism:
      • Binds to H2 receptors on parietal cells
      • Increases cAMP levels, activating H+/K+ ATPase to enhance acid secretion
  • Acetylcholine (Option C ruled out)
    • Source: Vagus nerve (parasympathetic stimulation)
    • Mechanism:
      • Binds to muscarinic receptors on parietal cells
      • Increases intracellular calcium, stimulating H+/K+ ATPase activity
  • Other Factors
    • Amino Acids: Stimulate gastrin release, indirectly increasing acid secretion
    • Ghrelin: Secreted by the stomach, potentially enhancing acid secretion

questions.text: A patient presented with severe watery diarrhea resembling that of rice gruel stool. Damage of which structure is likely to have resulted in this diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Rice gruel stools are characteristic of cholera, caused by Vibrio cholerae infection. The cholera toxin leads to severe watery diarrhea by disrupting the intestinal epithelial barrier and increasing intestinal chloride secretion.

  • The zona occludens (tight junctions) are crucial for maintaining the integrity of the intestinal epithelial barrier by regulating paracellular permeability and preventing leakage of fluids and electrolytes between epithelial cells.
  • In cholera, the toxin disrupts tight junctions, causing increased permeability and massive loss of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, resulting in the characteristic watery diarrhea.

Gap Junction (Option B): Gap junctions are responsible for cell-to-cell communication via ionic and metabolic coupling. They are not involved in maintaining epithelial barrier function or preventing diarrhea.

Adherens Junction (Option C): These junctions mediate cell-cell adhesion and help maintain tissue architecture. While important for structural integrity, their disruption is less directly linked to diarrhea compared to tight junctions.

Hemidesmosomes (Option D): Hemidesmosomes anchor epithelial cells to the basement membrane and play a role in resisting mechanical stress. They are not involved in regulating intestinal permeability or the development of diarrhea.

questions.solution:

questions.text: What is the most probable outcome for a patient who has undergone complete ileal and partial jejunal resection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vitamin B12 deficiency

Explanation:

Vitamin B12 deficiency is the most probable outcome for a patient who has undergone complete ileal and partial jejunal resection because:

  • The ileum is the primary site for the absorption of vitamin B12. When the ileum is removed or severely damaged, the absorption of vitamin B12 is impaired, leading to a deficiency.
  • The jejunum primarily absorbs nutrients like carbohydrates, proteins, and some vitamins, but it is not the main site for vitamin B12 absorption.

Folic acid deficiency (option A): Folic acid is primarily absorbed in the proximal small intestine, especially in the duodenum and jejunum, and while resection may impair absorption, it is more commonly a concern with extensive jejunal resection. In this case, vitamin B12 deficiency is more likely than folic acid deficiency.

Gastric ulcer (option C): Gastric ulcers are not directly related to ileal or jejunal resection. However, vitamin B12 deficiency could lead to pernicious anemia, which affects the stomach's ability to secrete intrinsic factor, essential for B12 absorption, but this is not the same as gastric ulcers.

Constipation (option D): Constipation is a common issue after small bowel resection, especially with significant loss of the jejunum, but it is not the most likely or most immediate outcome compared to vitamin B12 deficiency, which is more directly related to ileal resection.

questions.text: Which of the following functions is NOT attributed to the intestinal epithelium?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Bile salts secretion

Explanation:

  • Bile salts are produced in the liver and stored in the gallbladder. They are released into the small intestine when needed to aid in the digestion and absorption of fats.
  • Bile salts emulsify large fat molecules, breaking them down into smaller droplets, which increases the efficiency of fat digestion by enzymes.

 

Functions of intestinal epithelium:

Paneth cells

  • Specialised immune cells found in the intestinal crypts of Lieberkuhn, primarily in the small intestine.
  • They are known for secreting antimicrobial peptides, such as defensins and lysozymes, which help protect the gut against infections.

 

Goblet cells (Option C ruled out)

  • Goblet cells are specialised epithelial cells throughout the intestines that secrete mucus.
  • This mucus forms a protective layer over the epithelial surface, safeguarding the intestinal lining from mechanical and chemical damage.

 

Enteroendocrine cells

  • Enteroendocrine cells are scattered throughout the gastrointestinal tract and produce hormones like serotonin, gastrin, and cholecystokinin.
  • These hormones are involved in digestion, appetite regulation, and gut motility.

 

Enterocytes (Option A ruled out)

  • Enterocytes are the absorptive cells lining the intestinal villi that absorb nutrients such as carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, and minerals.

 

Exocrine cells

  • These cells in the mucosa of the small intestine secrete mucus, peptidase, sucrase, maltase, lactase, lipase, and enterokinase.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient underwent an endoscopic examination of the gastrointestinal tract due to recurrent abdominal discomfort and altered bowel habits. Identify the arrow-marked structure in the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Bruner gland

Explanation:

  • The given histology slide is of duodenum.
  • Identification points:
    • Wall made up of four layers.
    • Mucosa presence of numerous broad villi lined by simple columnar epithelium with microvilli and goblet cells.
    • Presence of crypts of lieberkuhn. (Option C ruled out)
    • Presence of submucous Brunner's gland.
  • The marked structure by the arrow is of Brunner's gland (mucus secreting glands - to protect from stomach acids).

 

Interstitial cells of kajal (Option B): They are stellate mesenchymal pacemaker cells with smooth muscle-like features that send long, multiply branched processes into the intestinal smooth muscle, generating the basal electrical rhythm (BER). This option is incorrect.

Peyer’s patches (Option D): They are lymphoid tissues especially in terminal 25 cm of the ileum. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: A patient who has undergone gastrectomy (surgical removal of part or all of the stomach) is at risk of deficiencies in certain nutrients. Which of the following vitamins is most likely to require supplementation in such a patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Vitamin B12:

  • A patient who has undergone gastrectomy is at risk of vitamin B12 deficiency due to the reduced production of intrinsic factor, which is necessary for vitamin B12 absorption. Therefore, vitamin B12 supplementation is typically required to prevent deficiency in such patients.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vitamin C: Although vitamin C is important for immune function and skin health, deficiency is not typically a direct result of gastrectomy. Patients may get enough vitamin C through their diet or supplements without specific concern related to gastrectomy.

Option B - Vitamin D: Vitamin D is crucial for bone health and calcium absorption. While vitamin D deficiency can occur in various conditions, it is not specifically linked to gastrectomy. Patients may need to monitor vitamin D levels, but it is not the primary concern post-gastrectomy.

Option D - Vitamin A: Vitamin A is important for vision, skin health, and immune function. Deficiency in vitamin A is less commonly associated with gastrectomy compared to vitamin B12.

questions.text: Which of the following acts as a secondary messenger in the mechanism of gastric acid secretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - cAMP: 

  • cAMP and calcium act as secondary messengers for the hormones acting on the H+ K+ ATPase in the parietal cell.
  • cAMP and calcium activates protein kinase A, which phosphorylates the H+/K+ ATPase pump, increasing acid secretion into the lumen.
  • Hormones acting through cAMP as a secondary messenger are prostaglandin E2 and histamine.
  • Hormones acting through calcium as a secondary messenger are gastrin and acetylcholine.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - cGMP: While cGMP is involved in the regulation of some gastrointestinal functions, such as smooth muscle relaxation.

Option C - CCK-B receptor: The CCK-B receptor is involved in the regulation of pancreatic enzyme secretion and gallbladder contraction.

Option D - Ach: While Ach is involved in the activation of parietal cells, it is not a secondary messenger in the mechanism of gastric acid secretion.

questions.text: Which of the following functions is NOT attributed to the intestinal epithelium?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bile salts secretion:

  • Bile salts are produced in the liver and stored in the gallbladder. They are released into the small intestine when needed to aid in the digestion and absorption of fats. Bile salts emulsify large fat molecules, breaking them down into smaller droplets, which increases the efficiency of fat digestion by enzymes.

 

Incorrect Options: 

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect. All these functions are carried out by intestinal epithelium.

questions.text: Which co-transporter is primarily responsible for facilitating glucose absorption across the basolateral membrane of an enterocytein this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - GLUT2: 

  • Glucose Transporter Type 2 (GLUT2) is a protein that helps with glucose transport across cell membranes. In the small intestine, GLUT2 is found on the basolateral membrane of enterocytes (intestinal cells), where it facilitates the transport of glucose from these cells into the bloodstream.

 

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - SGLT1: Sodium-Glucose Transport Protein 1 (SGLT1) is a protein that aids in sodium and glucose co-transport in the apical membrane of the enterocytes.

Option C - GLUT5: Glucose Transporter Type 5 (GLUT5) facilitates the fructose absorption by facilitated diffusion from interstitium to enterocytes.

Option D - SGLT2: Sodium-Glucose Transport Protein 2 (SGLT2) is another sodium glucose co-transporter that aids in glucose absorption in the kidney.

questions.text: On which receptor does Hepcidin act to hinder the absorption of iron?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ferroportin:

  • Ferroportin is a transmembrane protein facilitating iron release from cells like enterocytes and macrophages.
  • Hepcidin, produced by the liver, regulates iron levels by binding to ferroportin, triggering its internalization and degradation, thereby reducing iron release into the bloodstream. This inhibition decreases iron absorption from the intestines and iron release from macrophages, resulting in decreased iron levels in circulation.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - DMT-1: DMT-1 (divalent metal transporter 1) is a transmembrane protein responsible for transporting iron into cells.

Option C - Hephaestin: Hephaestin is an enzyme involved in iron metabolism, particularly in the release of iron from enterocytes into the bloodstream.

Option D - Transferrin: Transferrin is a protein that binds to iron in the bloodstream and transports it to cells.

questions.text: What are the effects of dietary fibers?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Reduces intestinal transit time:

  • Dietary fibers are known to increase stool bulk and promote regular bowel movements, thus reducing intestinal transit time. They add bulk to the stool, making it easier to pass through the digestive system and preventing constipation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - No role in metabolism:

  • This is incorrect because dietary fibers play a significant role in metabolism. They are not digested by human enzymes, but they are fermented by gut bacteria in the colon, producing short-chain fatty acids that can be utilized as an energy source.

Option C - Causes constipation:

  • This is incorrect because dietary fibers actually help prevent constipation. They add bulk to the stool, soften it, and promote regular bowel movements.

Option D - Increased blood Glucose:

  • This is incorrect because dietary fibers have the opposite effect on blood glucose levels. Soluble fibers, in particular, can slow down the absorption of glucose, leading to a more gradual and controlled rise in blood glucose levels after a meal.

questions.text: Which part of the liver stores vitamin A?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ito cells:

  • Ito cells, also known as hepatic stellate cells, are responsible for storing vitamin A in the liver. These cells are found in the space of Disse, which is located between the hepatocytes and endothelial cells in the liver sinusoids. Ito cells store vitamin A as lipid droplets within their cytoplasm.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation

questions.text: Which hormone among the following does not exert its effects on the pancreas?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Gastrin:

  • This option suggests that gastrin does not act on the pancreas. However, gastrin does have an indirect effect on the pancreas. Gastrin is released by the stomach in response to the presence of food and stimulates the secretion of gastric acid. The release of gastric acid can indirectly affect pancreatic function by modulating the release of other hormones involved in pancreatic secretion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Secretin: Secretin is a hormone that acts on the pancreas. It is released by the duodenum in response to low pH in the stomach. Secretin stimulates the pancreas to secrete bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice, which helps neutralize the acidic chyme entering the small intestine.

Option C - Cholecystokinin: Cholecystokinin (CCK) is a hormone that acts on the pancreas. It is released by the duodenum in response to the presence of fatty acids and amino acids. CCK stimulates the secretion of pancreatic enzymes, such as lipase and amylase, to aid in the digestion of fats and carbohydrates.

Option D - GIP (Glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide): GIP is a hormone that acts on the pancreas. It is released by the small intestine in response to the ingestion of glucose and fatty acids. GIP stimulates the release of insulin from pancreatic beta cells, which helps regulate blood glucose levels.

questions.text: The following Darrow Yannet diagram is suggestive of which condition? Note: The solid line is the original fluid compartment and the color shaded compartment with the dotted change caused by the condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Adrenal insufficiency: 

  • Adrenal insufficiency, or Addison's disease, results from insufficient cortisol production by the adrenal glands. Symptoms include fatigue, weight loss, low blood pressure, and electrolyte imbalances.
  • In the Darrow Yannet diagram, it leads to decreased extracellular fluid (ECF) and increased intracellular fluid (ICF) due to hormonal imbalances.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Excessive sweating, or hyperhidrosis, involves uncontrollable sweating in specific body areas. However, it's not typically represented in a Darrow Yannet diagram.

Option C - Diarrhea causes fluid and electrolyte losses, leading to a decrease in the extracellular fluid compartment. However, without more context, it's unclear if the diagram specifically represents diarrhea.

Option D -: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) results in excess ADH production, leading to water retention and expansion of the extracellular fluid compartment, as shown in the Darrow Yannet diagram.
